message: Our intelligence community’s mission is to speak truth to power. It is flabbergasting to question & disrespect the thousands of intelligence professionals who keep us safe.
Repeal of the Obamacare without a proper replacement would mean chaos to the healthcare market & a spike in premiums. Let’s work to fix the law instead of leaving 30 million without insurance.

Members of our nation’s military represent every religion, race, and creed, and both Sikhs and Muslims serve honorably and heroically in the U.S. military. This action by the Army, which is long overdue, ensures Sikh and Muslim soldiers need not compromise their religious beliefs in order to serve. I have long advocated for this policy change to be replicated across all military branches, and hope the incoming Administration will uphold this policy.

Today’s report is well in line with previous assessments from the intelligence community that Russian officials at the highest levels engaged in an unprecedented level of interference in our elections, and these actions had the goal of harming the candidacy of Hillary Clinton and boosting the candidacy of President-elect Donald Trump. This report demonstrates the important role of our nation’s intelligence community and the men and women who work quietly every day to keep our country safe.   The strength of America’s democracy will be measured, in part, on how we respond, and the steps we take to develop a robust and proactive cyber strategy, including tools and capabilities to deter and effectively respond to future attempts by foreign actors to influence America’s democratic process.

Our strength and that of our democracy will be measured by our actions.  The American people expect us to act on this unprecedented attack on our democratic institutions by Russia.

Anybody who thinks it is a good idea to repeal the ACA without even the hint of a viable replacement plan does not understand how markets work. The uncertainty created by the GOP's flawed, political strategy will fundamentally destabilize the healthcare system. More than 20 million Americans will be left in the lurch, including nearly 700,000 Virginians.   There is a smarter way to do this, and I have long advocated for targeted, commonsense improvements to the ACA that will reduce costs and ease requirements on employers. But tonight's "show vote" to repeal it without a plan to replace it is bad for businesses, bad for Virginians, and will bring chaos to the healthcare market.

Today, we celebrate Dr. King and his legacy. To honor his memory & commitment to justice, I encourage you to participate in this National Day of Service. Visit MLKDay.gov to find a service project for #MLKDay or a year-round volunteer opportunity in your community. #NationalDayofService
We still have a long ways to go on Metro safety, but incremental, small steps like these still matter.

Nominee for the Department of Health and Human Services Rep. Tom Price said today that nobody wants to “pull the rug out on anyone” on ACA repeal. If that’s the case, why did GOP jam through a late-night vote last week to repeal it without offering a viable replacement? We can’t afford to #MakeAmericaSickAgain
Men of quality embrace equality

Great meeting with the Virginia Sheriffs' Association (VSA) this morning, where we discussed ways Congress can support them as they protect our communities. Substantive, important conversation about expanding the use of technology like modernized DNA testing and body cameras. We also talked about ways to address the growing burdens placed on law enforcement and the court system as a result of drug abuse and the opioid epidemic.

FACT: Our federal workforce is, in fact, smaller today than it was under President Reagan. As I told President Trump’s nominee for OMB Director today, federal employees serve our country with purpose and pride – they shouldn’t be political punching bags.

A ban on torture is not simply a matter of policy – it is U.S. law. I will not accept any attempt by this Administration to circumvent that policy, directly or through others.   I have spoken this morning with CIA Director Pompeo and Secretary of Defense Mattis and reiterated that any attempt by this Administration to restart torture is absolutely unacceptable, and I will strongly oppose it.  I intend to hold nominees, including Director Pompeo and Secretary Mattis, to their sworn testimony to follow the law banning the use of enhanced interrogation techniques. I will insist on similar ironclad assurances from DNI-designate Coats. And I will vigorously oppose any attempt to return to the ineffective practices of the past, and actively encourage my colleagues to do the same.

I remain committed to a comprehensive immigration plan that strengthens our nation’s borders, improves our legal immigration system to support our security and economic needs, and finds a practical solution for the millions of undocumented immigrants currently residing in the United States.    Without meaningful reforms to our immigration system, a piecemeal approach will resolve some problems while making others worse, and may even create unforeseen challenges down the road. No matter how many billions of dollars we spend on border security, if we don’t fix our visa system to make legal entry more attractive than illegal entry, we’ll still have the same problem we started with.

I respect Sen. Sessions’ service to Alabama and to the nation, but I cannot support his nomination to serve as U.S. Attorney General.  Sen. Sessions’ opposition to bipartisan, commonsense policies relating to voting rights, anti-discrimination, domestic violence protections and criminal justice reform, among others, have resulted in thousands of Virginians voicing significant concerns about this nomination. I share their concerns.     Attorney General is one of the most important positions in a president’s Cabinet, tasked with enforcing laws and protecting the civil rights of all Americans. Sen. Sessions’ long record in opposition to these ideals gives me concern that he is not the right person to serve as Attorney General.

The Trump Administration executive order that indefinitely suspends the Syrian refugee program and pauses visas from Muslim countries runs counter to our American values. While I have always been open to a pause on our refugee program to ensure appropriate time for intelligence and law enforcement experts to ensure we protect our national security, these actions by the President presume the solution before the review is complete. It is a policy targeting Muslims that national security experts have testified would harm, not help, our national security interests. I join the interfaith community in Virginia and around the country in objecting to these moves, and I will work in Congress to block an effort which trades dubious increases in U.S. security for certain alienation of partners with whom we must cooperate to address terrorism.

This is not the way to treat those who have helped this country in the fight against terrorism. End this dangerous #MuslimBan   “Shortly after noon on Saturday, Hameed Khalid Darweesh, an interpreter who worked on behalf of the United States government in Iraq, was released. After nearly 19 hours of detention, Mr. Darweesh began to cry as he spoke to reporters, putting his hands behind his back and miming handcuffs.  ‘What I do for this country? They put the cuffs on,' Mr. Darweesh said. 'You know how many soldiers I touch by this hand?’”
The President has created chaos and fear in our country & around the world. We are demanding answers from the Administration on this misguided and un-American immigration order.

As the President’s principal economic adviser, the position of Treasury Secretary holds a special significance.  The Treasury Department must ensure America’s debts are paid, strengthen our role as a global economic power, and oversee policies which are very important to America’s economic and national security.  Based on Mr. Mnuchin’s record, my meeting with him, his answers during the Senate Finance hearing and follow-on questioning, I am unable to support his nomination to serve as Treasury Secretary.   Throughout the confirmation process, Mr. Mnuchin has failed to adequately demonstrate that he will be a forceful advocate for innovative policies that will make the U.S. economy work better for the majority of Americans. I also am not convinced that he is committed to robust enforcement of Dodd-Frank Wall Street reforms, which are intended to protect taxpayers from the sort of irresponsible behavior that triggered the 2008 financial crisis.  Further, I am concerned by Mr. Mnuchin’s lack of understanding of the critical role the Treasury Department plays in both crafting and implementing economic sanctions, and his focus on using an unproven scoring method to pay for tax cuts.  Given these concerns, I have determined that Mr. Mnuchin is not the right candidate to serve as Secretary of the Treasury, and I will vote against his nomination.
Senate Democrats are rallying in front of the Supreme Court against President Trump's un-American immigration order. WATCH LIVE:

Rep. Tom Price is the wrong choice for a healthcare system that is affordable, accessible and provides high quality care. I will strongly oppose his nomination.

Help me make the case against repealing the Affordable Care Act. With a short video or through our website, I want hear how the ACA has helped you, your family, or a friend. Use the hashtag #VAis4coverage  Click HERE: http://bit.ly/2kLGoiG

Like many of you, I’m deeply troubled by the President’s reorganization of the National Security Council, which added his chief political advisor while diminishing the roles of two top military and intelligence officials. For 70 years, presidents of both parties have tried to honor a firewall between politics and policy – until President Trump signed the NSC reorganization order last weekend. Political considerations should not play a role in national security decisions, so today I introduced legislation that would permanently keep intelligence and military experts as charter members of the NSC.

I can’t support President Trump’s pick for Budget Director. Rep. Mulvaney’s use of the threat of a government shutdown or debt default as a political bargaining chip is deeply irresponsible, and the across-the-board sequestration cuts that he has supported have hurt our military and allowed lawmakers to avoid making tough budget decisions. We need someone who is committed to thinking strategically about the challenges our federal workers will face in the coming years, and he is not that person.

Congress will not stand for a return to torture.  We’ve been clear to Defense Secretary Mattis & CIA Director Pompeo: torture is immoral & illegal, and we will strongly oppose any action by the Administration to go back to these banned practices.

Did you know Virginia is one of Cuba’s biggest trading partners? Last year, farmers and producers sold more than $40 million worth of Virginia soybeans, apples, poultry and pork to Cuba. Increased exposure to American values like capitalism will not only help the Cuban people pressure their government for change, but it can also help support the agricultural industry and create good jobs here in Virginia. That’s why I introduced a bill that would lift restrictions on private financing of agricultural products to Cuba.
The U.S. doesn't torture. I will oppose any efforts by this Administration to take us back to the failed policies of the past.

I voted against Betsy DeVos' nomination once on Friday. I'll vote against her nomination to be Education Secretary again on Tuesday, and will be urging my colleagues to do the same. Thank you, Virginians, for staying engaged in this debate. It's so important for our children's future.

The Senate voted today by the most narrow margin in its history to confirm a Secretary of Education who does not demonstrate a firm grasp on even the most basic education policy principles.  Since Ms. DeVos’ nomination, tens of thousands of my constituents have expressed serious concerns about her focus on charter schools and voucherizing federal education dollars. Educators and parents of students with special needs are rightfully concerned, as am I, about Ms. DeVos’ lack of understanding or even awareness of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act.  During her confirmation hearing, she demonstrated a similar lack of awareness of federal education policies related to campus sexual assault and school safety.   While I did not support Ms. DeVos’ confirmation, I intend to hold her accountable for serving our students’, teachers’, parents’, and school leaders’ best interests, and I look forward to looking for areas of agreement where possible.

I have serious doubts about whether Senator Sessions will be sufficiently independent from this Administration to execute the responsibilities of Attorney General. But it is his long record of opposition to bipartisan & commonsense policies on voting rights, civil rights, domestic violence, and criminal justice reform that give me the gravest concern about this nomination. I plan to vote NO tonight.
Watch my response to Senator Ben Sasse on the Constitution and the separation of powers in the age of President Trump:

I cannot think of another nominee I’ve been asked to consider who has, over the course of a career, demonstrated more disdain for the work of the agency he seeks to lead than Mr. Pruitt. From opposing Chesapeake Bay cleanup, to denying the science of climate change, to filing more than a dozen lawsuits against the Environmental Protection Agency, Mr. Pruitt's views and actions do not align with what once was a bipartisan national priority of protecting our nation's air and water.  After a close review of his record, prior statements, and Committee testimony, I am convinced that Mr. Pruitt would use this position to undermine those goals. Virginia simply has too much at stake for Mr. Pruitt to become Administrator of the EPA. I will be voting against this nomination, and encouraging my colleagues to do the same.

Steve Mnuchin’s record shows he is not the right candidate to lead the Treasury Department and help middle class families succeed. While I voted no tonight, I will press him to pursue responsible fiscal policy that protects taxpayers and the long-term health of our financial system.

Reports that the White House may have been briefed weeks ago on the nature of Gen. Flynn's calls raise deeply troubling questions. The American people deserve to know at whose direction Gen. Flynn was acting when he made these calls, and why the White House waited until these reports were public to take action.   These developments underscore how many questions still remain unanswered to the American people more than three months after Election Day, including who was aware of what, and when. This reinforces both the urgency and the significance of the Senate Intelligence Committee's bipartisan investigation into Russian interference, which will include a thorough examination of contacts between Russia and individuals associated with political campaigns, as well as interviews with current and former government officials.   Nothing about this resignation, or resignations that could occur in the future, precludes the Senate Intelligence Committee from continuing to investigate Gen. Flynn, or any other campaign official who may have had inappropriate and improper contacts with Russian officials prior to the election.  It is clear that our task is more urgent than ever.

We honored three shining stars from NASA Langley Research Center with a special screening  of #HiddenFigures at the U.S. Capitol. Katherine Johnson, Dorothy Vaughan and Mary Jackson broke barriers at NASA in science, engineering and math in the days before computers. I was proud to honor them and their families tonight for their valuable contributions, and their stories inspired a theater full of smart young people from across Northern Virginia.

Last night was pretty awesome. We honored three magnificent role models & told their story by screening the movie Hidden Figures. But the coolest part was getting to meet these Prince William County students excited to pursue futures in STEM.

Immigrants are an integral part of Virginia’s culture and economy. That’s why recent immigration enforcement actions like those that occurred at Rising Hope Mission Church in Fairfax County – where ICE agents waited outside a hypothermia shelter operated by the church so that they could arrest six men as they left – are troubling and only serve to instill fear and uncertainty in our immigrant communities. I’m inviting the pastor of this church, Rev. Keary Kincannon, to be my guest to the President’s address to Congress next week. My hope is that this will send a message to President Trump: these actions diminish the immigrant community’s trust and cooperation with law enforcement, and they hurt Virginia’s families, neighborhoods, and communities.
Extremely concerned by increased threats and acts of anti-Semitism in Va. & across U.S. Must be denounced in the strongest possible terms.

Meet my guest to tonight’s #JointSession: Rev. Dr. Keary Kincannon from Fairfax County. His church, Rising Hope United Methodist Mission Church, helps the homeless & protects immigrants in our communities.

#ICYMI: Discussing this morning on Face The Nation the Intel Committee's investigation into Russian interference in our election. This is as serious as anything I've ever been involved in.

While this executive order may avoid some of the administrative and procedural issues associated with the Administration’s initial EO, improving the implementation of a poor policy still results in poor policy.   There is no evidence that immigrants from the countries listed in the EO pose a heightened threat to our security. There are serious people at the Department of Homeland Security and within the intelligence community who have been considering this issue for years. Perhaps a better approach would be to allow them to recommend what our policy should be.

Trumpcare, the House Republican plan to replace the Affordable Care Act, will cover less and cost more, and lead millions of Americans to lose coverage altogether.   Trumpcare cuts and caps Medicaid, which means a state like Virginia which did not expand Medicaid gets the short end of the stick. In addition, the taxes on very wealthy people which helped pay for the ACA are eliminated under Trumpcare, and the House is rushing this bill through without saying how much it adds to the budget deficit.   Instead of improving what we have, Trumpcare seems designed to cover fewer Americans, and makes that coverage less generous and less affordable.

They might not wear a uniform while they do it, but make no mistake – those who care for our veterans are providing an invaluable service to our country.  Military caregivers carry a unique burden by caring for loved ones who come home bearing the physical and emotional scars of war. Our legislation recognizes their contributions and provides caregivers with additional resources to help them care for our nation’s veterans.
NA

Today’s estimates from the Congressional Budget Office show that Trumpcare will raise costs for consumers, particularly seniors, and leave millions of Americans without coverage. This irresponsible approach shifts costs to states by radically restructuring and cutting Medicaid – a critical safety net that insures more than 600,000 children in Virginia, as well as thousands of elderly and disabled Virginians who depend on the program for services and long-term care – in order to cut taxes for the wealthiest Americans.   Republicans and Democrats alike should be deeply disturbed by ongoing attacks on the impartial budget experts at the CBO. For decades, Congress has agreed that having the CBO as our referee is the best way to ensure that estimates like today’s come from unbiased experts, not from people pushing their own political agendas. Shooting the messenger can’t hide the fact that millions of Americans will be worse off under Trumpcare.  Read the CBO report here--> http://bit.ly/2mkACEb

This budget proposal from President Trump does not reflect a balanced approach.  Instead, it includes many short-sighted choices that if implemented could actually harm our country's strength and long-term growth.  The Trump budget proposes to dramatically slash public investments in programs like early childhood education, job training, scientific research, and the protection of economic and natural resources like the Chesapeake Bay. We should be serious about addressing the fiscal issues in our country and work together to address the impact that the across-the-board spending cuts have had on the military and our national security.  However, the road map the President has laid out does not meet those goals. I urge him to commit to working with Congress to take a more responsible, businesslike approach – one that also respects the role of smart investments in our nation’s economic future.
Hate has no place on our college campuses. These anti-Semitic acts are unacceptable & must be strongly condemned.

Virginia’s native tribes have played a key role in shaping the history of this country. We must do the right thing & pass this legislation which formally recognizes their contribution & grants them access to the services they’re entitled to.

Joined U.S. Senator Tim Kaine on a call with Virginia hospitals today to talk about #Trumpcare, which is set to be voted on Thursday in the House. This is a bad bill for Virginians and for Virginia hospitals: 232,000 Virginians will lose health coverage, and Virginia hospitals would see $209 million in uncompensated care by 2018.  This House Republican proposal slashes Medicaid coverage for kids, the disabled and the poor, and it undermines Medicare.

As the first person in my family to graduate from college, I would not have had the chance to be a successful entrepreneur if I had left college with overwhelming student loan debt. Today I introduced two bipartisan bills to help younger borrowers manage their student loan debt better and incentivize businesses to help pay off their employees’ student debt in a tax-free way, both which will provide relief to the growing number of borrowers that are struggling with the crippling effects of student loan debt.  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2oIfwBd

Last night, the Director of National Intelligence briefed me on the Administration's strikes in Syria. Assad's use of chemical weapons to slaughter civilians was a heinous crime as well as a violation of international norms and Syria's commitments to give up chemical weapons. It could not go unpunished. I am hopeful these strikes will convince the Assad regime that such actions should never be repeated.    I have requested information from the Administration about their plans, including any additional action in response to the use of chemical weapons. President Trump has said repeatedly that his objective in Syria is to defeat ISIS. Last night's strike was aimed at a different objective. President Trump needs to articulate a coherent strategy for dealing with this complex conflict, because the consequences of a misstep are grave.

Today we commemorate Yom HaShoah, Holocaust Rememberance Day. With anti-Semitic incidents on the rise in the United States, it is more important than ever that we stand up to prejudice and hate. This is a time to not only remember the victims of the Holocaust, but to make sure such a tragedy never happens again.

I can think of no higher honor for a high school student than serving our country and attending one of its service academies. That’s why I’m honored to host our annual Academy Day this Saturday in Charlottesville. If you know a Virginia student who is up to the challenge, tag him or her in the comments.
228 years ago today, George Washington raised his right hand and became our nation’s first President. Our country is forever indebted to this great Virginian for his leadership and service.
Partisan budget showdowns and short-term spending bills are no way to govern. President Trump and the congressional majority owe it to taxpayers to prevent a shutdown.

My friends from the United Mine Workers of America spent their careers in Southwest Virginia’s coal mines working hard to power America’s economy. If Congress doesn’t act, they’re going to lose their healthcare tomorrow. The President and Congressional Republicans need to do the right thing for these miners and their families.

Introduced a bipartisan bill today creating cybersecurity standards for federal Internet-of-Things purchases. I'm excited about the innovation happening in the IoT space, but we need some common sense cybersecurity standards. It's time to raise the bar for federal IoT security.

First we were told that President Trump was not involved in drafting his son's statement on his meeting with Russians in Trump Tower. Now we learn the President himself may have dictated a statement that appears to have intentionally deceived the American people. If the Trump Administration wants us to believe that there’s nothing to the Russia investigation, they need to be start acting like it.

For years, I’ve been working to cut the red tape holding up Virginia’s new VA healthcare clinics. After countless hearings, letters, and phone calls with VA and budget officials, and after listening to the Virginia veterans who are waiting on the federal government to get its act together, we are so close to the finish line. We’re going to get this done for our veterans.

This bill is great news for Virginia veterans: it contains language I’ve been pushing for years to speed up new VA clinics in Hampton Roads and Fredericksburg, and I’m looking forward to seeing these clinics up and running ASAP. We also passed a bill to reform the often slow  and frustrating claims appeal process at the Department of Veterans Affairs. I'm proud to have supported these bipartisan veterans bills and glad to see them headed to the President's desk. This is how Congress is supposed to work.

I'm live on the Senate floor today to pay tribute to the men and women of our nation's intelligence community. As Vice-Chairman of the Senate Intel Committee, I've seen firsthand the incredible dedication of intelligence professionals who help keep our nation safe, far from the limelight and sworn to secrecy. Today, I just want to say thank you to each and every one of them for their service to our country.
PASSED: The Forever GI Bill expands educational opportunities for over 500,000 veterans. Proud to cosponsor it and looking forward to President Trump signing it into law.

I’m encouraged to see some of my Republican colleagues putting people before politics on this. The Affordable Care Act needs some fixes, but undermining it to score political points is dangerous and wrong. The fact that deliberate sabotage of the insurance market is even on the table for the White House should be disturbing to all Americans.
Wishing a happy 227th birthday to the U.S. Coast Guard, especially to all our Coast Guardsmen serving down in Hampton Roads. #SemperParatus #CG227
Cosponsored this bill to bring down Rx drug prices for our seniors. Allowing Medicare to negotiate the best deal is just common sense.

North Korea’s pursuit and development of nuclear weapons represent a serious threat to the security of the United States and our allies. However, President Trump's inflammatory rhetoric undermines our global credibility and is unlikely to de-escalate the situation. We need fewer fiery words and bombastic tweets from the President and his cable TV surrogates, and more effort to work with our international partners to expand missile defense and deterrence and put forward a strategy to roll back North Korea’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs.   On Saturday, the UN Security Council unanimously voted to impose new sanctions on North Korea, for the eighth time since its first nuclear test in 2006. While it’s a productive step, we need to focus on enforcement, and ensure that China in particular adheres to the terms of the sanctions.   It’s also imperative that the Trump Administration embrace a robust policymaking process to think through all of our options, and be prepared to be realistic about what response the North Korean threat might require. Improvising our way into a shooting war on the Korean peninsula without a plan puts us all at risk. Moreover, this crisis underscores the importance of sending nominations to the Senate for key national security positions, including an Ambassador to South Korea, an Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, and Assistant Secretary of Defense for Asian Pacific Security Affairs.

To the white nationalists descending on Charlottesville tomorrow: go back to where you came from. Hate has no place in Virginia.

As a result of the uncertainty, mixed signals and deliberate sabotage from the Trump Administration, some insurers will raise premiums and scale back their health insurance offerings in the individual market, which serves more than 400,000 people in Virginia. It is unfortunate that others, such as Anthem, are choosing to leave the marketplace altogether. President Trump has been playing politics with health care for months and now Virginians are paying the price.

Virginians mourn the life taken in this morning's events and reject this hateful violence in Charlottesville. We condemn the intolerance behind it and those who would pass it off as a legitimate political movement.   Those who traveled to Virginia to incite unrest don't understand the Virginia-born values that make our country great.   I have been in touch today with the Governor's Office and the Mayor, and stand prepared to help connect them with any additional federal resources that might be needed. My thoughts are with the victims, the great people of Charlottesville, and the police and first responders who restored order. I will continue to monitor the situation in Charlottesville and pray for its peaceful resolution.
Yesterday was a sad day for the Commonwealth. My condolences to the families and fellow officers of our two state troopers lost in Saturday's helicopter crash.

As I'm traveling through Virginia today, I'm thinking of Heather Heyer, victim of white supremacist terrorism in Charlottesville. The fact that some of these hate groups are claiming a victory after this tragedy reveals their dangerous agenda and disregard for human life.

Listened to members of the Roanoke Valley's agricultural community at today's roundtable in Catawba. We talked about conservation, job creation, and opening up new international markets for Virginia agriculture. I heard from farmers, professors, agribusiness leaders, and even the president of the local FFA chapter. They've got a lot of good ideas heading into next year's farm bill.
Looking forward to hosting a Facebook Live Town Hall this Friday at 11:00 AM. Got a question for me? Ask it using this form or comment below:

Really impressive to see how far Rural Retreat's Duchess Dairy Products has come since its founding in 2010. Looking ahead to the 2018 farm bill, the Huffard family and their co-owners have some good ideas for how we can help Virginia small agribusinesses like Duchess grow and compete.

This is not leadership. This is not what mayors, presidents, governors do in moments of crises. They call on us to rediscover our better angels, and unfortunately this President seems to take us in the opposite direction. It's hypocrisy that then-candidate Trump constantly challenged President Obama for not using the phrase ‘Islamic terrorism’ but now is unwilling to use that same standard to describe what happened, which was domestic terrorism by a neo-Nazi on Saturday. He is not willing to use that same standard. That’s not leadership. The ideas represented by these alt-right groups, there’s nothing in them that reflects America’s creed that we are all people equally created by the Creator. And frankly, it is an abomination to the values that we hold in Virginia and for that matter across the country.

Just got done visiting a Save-A-Lot in Danville recently re-opened by Honor Capital LLC, a veteran-owned business with a mission to eradicate food deserts. I'm excited to team up with them on my new bill that will help grocers like Honor Capital provide fresh, healthy food access to the over 1,000,000 Virginians who currently live miles away from the nearest grocery store.  Learn more about the bipartisan Healthy Food Access for All Americans Act: https://www.warner.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/8/sens-warner-moran-introduce-first-comprehensive-senate-bill-to-encourage-food-service-providers-to-help-eradicate-food-deserts

Great things are happening in Southside Virginia. These kids are learning how to code and build robots before they're old enough to drive. I promised the crowd at the CodeVA / Microsoft event in Mecklenburg County that I'll keep up the fight for cell coverage and broadband in Southside and Southwest. We're going to get it done, and there'll be no reason you have to leave Southside to get a high-tech, high-wage job.
I'm live for my first Facebook Live Town Hall. Ask me anything!
Farmers Roundtable #2 in Wythe County: listened to farmers and agribusiness leaders, talked immigration, the budget and the 2018 Farm Bill.
Covered a lot at our Tazewell town hall last week, but we all shared a focus on rural economic development, starting with broadband and cell coverage.
The Metro Safety Commission is now law, freeing up funds for needed safety improvements. VA, MD, DC should get it up & running ASAP.

In a good year, Greg's poultry farm can feed 85,000 Americans. He came to our Farmer's Roundtable to talk about the bipartisan work I'm doing with Sen. Thad Cochran to open the Chinese market back up to Virginia poultry exports. We're going to keep up the fight for farmers like Greg.

The DACA program was a promise to protect certain children of undocumented immigrants, who came to this country through no fault of their own, so they could safely come out of the shadows, attain legal status and realize their full potential. Over the years, the DREAMers have shown us their true character—working hard to become this nation’s next generation of students, entrepreneurs, and military men and women.  And while Congress has a responsibility to enact comprehensive immigration reform that provides them with a fair path to citizenship, which the Senate passed in 2013, we cannot let the Trump Administration’s disgraceful anti-immigrant policies leave nearly 800,000 DREAMers in limbo. Going back on our word threatens their safety, harms our economy and speaks volumes about who we are as a country.

It was an honor for U.S. Senator Tim Kaine and I to present our Senate resolution recognizing Police Department, City of Alexandria, Virginia's bravery in response to the 6/14 shooting at the Congressional Baseball Game practice. Their actions and those of the Capitol Police officers on scene saved many lives. I'm grateful every day for their courage and commitment.

I'm live on the Senate floor to call on Congress and President Trump to condemn the hate groups responsible for the violence in Charlottesville and to discuss the work ahead on hurricane relief and the federal budget.

President Trump & Congress must unequivocally condemn the white nationalist and neo-nazi hate groups behind the violence in Charlottesville. Our new bipartisan resolution sends a clear message: The United States rejects the forces of bigotry and hate.
This is a red flag for those of us who care deeply about student safety.

This breach involves the Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses, and credit card numbers of nearly half of all Americans. It is a threat to our economic security. Should Congress create a uniform data breach notification standard for attacks like this? Is it time to rethink data protection policies dealing with these large, centralized sets of highly sensitive data on millions of Americans? The Equifax Breach raises serious questions about cybersecurity that Congress must address head on and soon.
The Equifax Breach is the latest evidence that we need stronger data & cybersecurity standards to protect consumers’ most sensitive data.
Please keep those in Hurricane Irma's path in your thoughts this weekend. Virginia stands with our neighbors as they confront and recover from Irma.

If Congress doesn’t act in the coming months, 28,000 kids in Virginia and thousands more across the country will lose their health insurance. I’m glad the Senate Finance Committee is working in a bipartisan way to reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program, but we need to get this done quickly. I’m committed to putting our children before politics and seeing this through.
Focused on North Korea sanctions in this week's Banking Committee hearing. There are more steps we can take to turn up the pressure on NK.

On September 11, we remember the victims of that terrible day and the bravery of our first-responders. Let us never forget those we lost or the unity and resolve the United States showed in the aftermath of this national tragedy. #Remember911

No FDNY firehouse was harder hit on 9/11 than Engine 54/Ladder 4/Battalion 9, which lost all 15 members of the morning shift. In New York this morning, it was an honor for me to meet the firefighters carrying on their fallen colleagues’ legacy and say thank you.

Both Republicans and Democrats should have learned a lesson about the difficulty of trying to pass major legislation like tax reform without bipartisan support.  As hearings finally begin in the Senate Finance Committee this week, it’s my hope Congress will put together a meaningful tax reform package that can pass with support from both Republicans and Democrats.

Today the Senate passed unanimously my bipartisan resolution condemning white supremacist groups and the terrorist attack in Charlottesville. I hope my colleagues in the House will act on this resolution quickly and send it to President Trump for his signature. We can't hesitate or equivocate in condemning white nationalists, the KKK, neo-Nazis, or others who would spread hate and bigotry.
More explicit proof that Russia used Facebook to sow discord, divide Americans, and influence the 2016 election.

Important hearing today in the Senate Finance Committee on ways we can reduce healthcare costs, expand options, and increase coverage. This is how Congress is supposed to work: bipartisan hearings, with testimony from experts across the ideological spectrum on issues that are important to our constituents. I hope we will continue to work this way to find solutions that work for more Americans.
Tonight the House passed my resolution condemning hate groups and the Charlottesville attack. President Trump should send a clear message and sign it ASAP.

President Trump should do the right thing and sign this resolution into law. This bipartisan resolution passed with the support of all 535 members of Congress. We must send a clear message that our nation is 100% united against the forces of hate.
The American people deserve to know their government is serious about responding to the Equifax Breach and making sure it can’t happen again.

For months, I’ve worked with a bipartisan group of Senators, community leaders, and experts on the Bipartisan Policy Center Appalachia Initiative. Today we released our report outlining concrete steps to jumpstart the Appalachian economy and invest in the region’s health, workforce, and infrastructure. Read the full report: https://bipartisanpolicy.org/library/the-appalachia-initiative/
Yesterday I called on the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the Equifax Breach. Pleased to learn the FTC is taking action.
Reports that Russia spent $100,000 on Facebook ads to divide Americans and influence the 2016 election are just the tip of the iceberg.
Pleased President Trump signed my bipartisan resolution condemning hate groups and last month's deadly violence in Charlottesville. Unfortunately he still equivocates when he speaks.
Glad Anthem is re-entering the Virginia exchange. Now it's time for the Trump Administration to stop efforts to sabotage and destabilize the market.
New bill, same broken, partisan process. "Graham-Cassidy" is repeal and replace by another name.
Wishing a happy birthday to the USAF. Thank you to the men and women serving in the United States Air Force in Virginia and around the world.
Yes.

The Roanoke Times: “Appalachia is getting high-level attention in Washington for perhaps the first time since Lyndon Johnson launched the “war on poverty” in the 1960s.”   Proud to be leading this effort to rebuild the Appalachian economy.
Today it is against the law to deny someone coverage for a pre-existing condition. We can't go back.
To everyone celebrating Rosh Hashanah, Shanah Tovah, happy new year!

Honored to present Congressional Gold Medals to the family of Captain Andrew Maples, Jr. and Flight Officer Harold Bernard Maples, Documented Original Tuskegee Airmen from Petersburg, Va. Our country is forever indebted to the Maples family, seven of whom answered the call to serve – from the Harlem Hellfighters in WWI to the Tuskegee Airmen in WWII.
The title says it all.
Important and absolutely necessary first step. The American people deserve to know the truth about Russia’s interference in the 2016 election.

Celebrated the ribbon-cutting for the Katherine Johnson Computational Research Facility today at NASA Langley Research Center. More importantly it was an incredible honor to finally meet Dr. Johnson, the “Human Computer,” subject of Hidden Figures, and a great Virginian.
Unacceptably delayed, but relieved this is finally happening after months of pushing. We have to do better in the future.

The GOP's partisan fight to repeal healthcare has been declared dead before, and I'm not naive enough to think it's true now either. On Monday, the Senate Finance Committee will hold a hearing on the "Graham-Cassidy" healthcare repeal bill. This hearing shouldn't be mistaken for the thoughtful, bipartisan process that an issue as important as healthcare demands, but it's the path Republican leadership has chosen. As a member of the Finance Committee, I'm asking you to participate in this hearing in three ways:   1. Submit a statement for the record by emailing: GCHcomments@finance.senate.gov by 9:00 AM Monday morning. Tell your story, let Congress know what healthcare means to you. Your voice matters more than ever.  2. Share this post to spread the word.   3. Tune in to the hearing Monday at 2:00 PM ET. I will be broadcasting it on Facebook Live.  Yesterday, Senator McCain once again reminded us of what true statesmanship looks like. Now it's on us to show my Republican colleagues what active citizenship looks like in our Democracy.

If you haven't yet, please submit your statement for the Senate Finance Committee's hearing on the Graham-Cassidy healthcare repeal bill by 9:00 AM ET Monday. Email GCHcomments@finance.senate.gov and share this post to spread the word.

Aya Hijazi is a Virginian human rights activist who was held unjustly in an Egyptian prison for three years. After working with a bipartisan group of Senators to advocate for her release, it was great to finally meet Aya, who is home safe and doing well.
The MAREA Cable in Virginia Beach is the highest-capacity subsea cable to ever cross the Atlantic. Proud to celebrate its completion this week with Terry McAuliffe and U.S. Senator Tim Kaine.
The line for today's "Graham-Cassidy" healthcare repeal hearing is longer than the Comey Hearing line. Good. Tune in at 2PM.

Danté is a 15 year-old Virginian with a rare brain condition covered by Medicaid. He and his mom Marlo are waiting in line for today's "Graham-Cassidy" hearing. Danté and Marlo came up from Virginia Beach because healthcare is literally a life and death issue for them. Hear what she has to say.

Happening NOW: The Senate Finance Committee is holding a rushed, last-minute hearing to try to jam through the “Graham-Cassidy” healthcare repeal bill. I’m fighting with all I’ve got to stop it. WATCH:
Today’s show hearing on the "Graham-Cassidy" healthcare repeal bill was a travesty. We need real bipartisan healthcare fixes, not this.

The Equifax Breach was a travesty, and simply changing CEOs is not going to be enough. At this point, I question whether Equifax has the right to continue providing services with its current lack of attention to cybersecurity. Today I pressed SEC Chairman Clayton on what his agency is doing to get to the bottom of this. Watch:
I'm live with AARP Virginia for a healthcare tele-town hall. listen in: https://video.teleforumonline.com/video/streaming.php?client=10208
Frankly I don’t think they understand how serious this problem is.
Sending my best wishes to the Jewish community for a meaningful Yom Kippur and an easy fast.
Congratulations to Cherif Sadki of Gar-Field High School in Woodbridge, 2017 Virginia principal of the year!
Woke up to this tragic news. My heart is with the victims, their families, first-responders, and the people of Las Vegas.

Frustrated doesn’t begin to describe how I feel about this. While I’m hopeful the Senate Finance Committee will be able to pass a bipartisan extension of the Children’s Health Insurance Program in the coming days, that doesn’t excuse the fact that this program was allowed to lapse so we could have a show hearing on the GOP healthcare repeal bill last week. Millions of kids are counting on us to protect their healthcare, and we’re out of time to waste.
DREAMers who came here as children love our country and deserve a shot at the American dream. That's why I support the bipartisan DREAM Act.
LIVE: Update on the Senate Intelligence Committee's Russia Investigation will begin momentarily.

FACT: Russia attacked our democracy in 2016, and they will be back. If that doesn’t concern you, it should. Today Chairman Burr and I gave an update on the Senate Intel Committee’s investigation and where we go from here. Bottom line: we have questions that must be answered before Americans go to the polls in 2018. For the sake of our democracy and our national security, this investigation will continue until we get to the truth.

Nearly half of all Virginians were hacked in the Equifax breach. I questioned the now-retired CEO of Equifax in the Senate Banking Committee, and frankly his answers fell far short of what the American people deserve.
Closing this deadly loophole is something both parties should be able to agree on.
These Virginia DREAMers are hardworking students who should be worrying about graduation, not deportation. We must pass the DREAM Act ASAP.

Thinking back on when I ran into my friends from the United Mine Workers at my town hall in Tazewell. The last time I saw these guys, we were in DC fighting to save their healthcare. We were able to pass a bipartisan fix on their healthcare, but we’ve still got to make sure the Federal Government keeps its promise to Virginia’s retired mine workers when it comes to their pensions.  This week I joined with Senator Joe Manchin III and U.S. Senator Tim Kaine to introduce the bipartisan American Miners Pension Act. We’re going to keep up the fight until we secure the pensions of retired miners and their families from Virginia and across coal country.
My heart is with these communities who have been devastated by the California Wildfires. Praying for the missing and the first responders battling the fires.

Couldn't agree with the Bluefield Daily Telegraph more: "Keep in mind that these are the same brave men and women who helped to power our nation while laboring deep underground. Now it is up to Congress to ensure that they receive their hard-earned benefits."

The Trump Administration is determined to inject chaos and confusion through its unilateral efforts to sabotage the Affordable Care Act, even though these actions will again raise costs and limit healthcare choices for working families. There is no debate about the results of President Trump’s irresponsible actions in the past 24 hours. By taking a wrecking ball to the ACA, the Trump Administration has itself created additional hardship and anxiety for many Virginia families, and undermines real progress on the Senate’s bipartisan efforts to bring stability to the individual health care marketplace.
This is why we need more transparency in online political ads. Introducing legislation with Amy Klobuchar on this soon. Stay tuned.
Virginia’s kids and their families are counting on us to get this done. Congress must renew the Children's Health Insurance Program.

Do you know someone who hasn’t registered to vote? Today is the last day to register in Virginia before next month’s election. Tag your friends and family in the comment section to remind them to register today.
Gloria is a Virginian and a DREAMer I met this month. If you're not sure about the bipartisan DREAM Act, listen to Gloria's story.

This is how Congress is supposed to work. Grateful to Senator Lamar Alexander & Sen. Patty Murray for putting aside politics to reach a bipartisan deal. I’ve been fighting to stop the Administration’s sabotage of the healthcare market. Thankfully, this deal will prevent it from taking effect.
"Sabotage" — verb — to deliberately destroy, damage, or obstruct something, especially for political or military advantage.
Happening now: Amy Klobuchar & I are introducing the Honest Ads Act to bring transparency to online political ads.
I’m on the Senate floor fighting to stop a $1.5 TRILLION increase to the deficit. Watch Live:

Yesterday I introduced the Honest Ads Act, a bipartisan bill that will bring needed transparency and accountability to online political ads. Government hasn’t kept up with changing technology, and the result has been a lack of transparency in online political ads. The Honest Ads Act will hold politicians, special interests, and ad platforms accountable for the ads they run, just like we do for TV and radio ads. Another reason this is important — Russia attacked our democracy in 2016 armed with the tools of information warfare, including digital ads. This bill will also strengthen protections against foreign interference in our election. No more election ads paid for in rubles.
Disturbing and unacceptable. Today I sent a letter demanding answers about this law's impact on the government's response to the opioid crisis.
Honored to be a host of the 8th annual Virginia Women's Conference in Virginia Beach. #VAWC17
This is why I fought to stop the GOP budget increasing the deficit by $1.5 TRILLION in unpaid-for tax cuts.

Over 1,000,000 Virginians live in food deserts — areas without access to fresh, healthy food. This weekend in Norfolk, I visited the Foodbank of Southeastern Virginia and the Eastern Shore to talk about my bipartisan bill to end these food deserts.   Learn more about the Healthy Food Access for All Americans Act: https://www.warner.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/8/sens-warner-moran-introduce-first-comprehensive-senate-bill-to-encourage-food-service-providers-to-help-eradicate-food-deserts
Americans deserve to know who’s paying for the political ads they see online.
No more excuses, no more delays. 65,000+ Virginia kids are on the verge of losing their healthcare. We must reauthorize the Children's Health Insurance Program now.
I actually believe it would be easier to pass a bipartisan Tax Reform deal with 60+ votes than a partisan bill with *maybe* 50 GOP votes. Here’s where I stand on tax reform.
Forced arbitration clauses prevent consumers from having their day in court. Repealing this rule is just bad for consumers.
Reason #1,000,000,000,000 to not increase the deficit by another 1.5 TRILLION in unpaid-for tax cuts.
So you’re telling me they wasted $1,000,000 in taxpayer money just to make it harder for people to get health insurance? That’s sabotage.
Healthcare for over 65,000 kids who rely on CHIP here in Virginia is on the line. The Senate needs to vote on a bipartisan Children's Health Insurance deal.
NA

Today’s indictments of two top Trump campaign officials, including former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort, is a significant and sobering step in what will be a complex and likely lengthy investigation by the Special Counsel. That is why it is imperative that Congress take action now to protect the independence of the Special Counsel, wherever or however high his investigation may lead. Members of Congress, Republican and Democrat, must also make clear to the President that issuing pardons to any of his associates or to himself would be unacceptable, and result in immediate, bipartisan action by Congress.   We have also learned this morning that, during this investigation, George Papadopoulos made false statements to the FBI about his contacts with Russians at the same time he was serving as an adviser to the Trump campaign. This is just the latest in a series of undisclosed contacts, misleading public statements, potentially compromising information, and highly questionable actions from the time of the Trump campaign that together, remain a cause for deep concern and continued investigation.    The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will continue its bipartisan probe into Russian meddling in the 2016 Presidential election.
ATTN: Virginia Voters    Today is the last day to request a mail-in ballot.   Request yours here by 5pm: https://www.elections.virginia.gov/casting-a-ballot/absentee-voting/
LIVE: America's tech firms testify before the Senate Intel Committee on Russia's use of social media in the 2016 election.

Yesterday some of America’s largest tech companies testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee about Russia’s interference in the 2016 election via social media. Frankly I was pretty frustrated with how long it’s taken for the leadership of these companies to take this issue seriously. Russia will be back, and it’s on all of us — tech firms, government, and the American people – to deal with this real and ongoing threat.

This tax plan was drafted by congressional Republicans behind closed doors, with no bipartisan input.  Democrats have ideas about how to grow our economy, help the middle-class, and improve our competitiveness through tax reform. This backroom proposal is not a responsible way to construct sound policy, particularly with something as complex and important to our economy as the tax code.

Watch this. Senator Klobuchar and I created fictional political organizations and ran this ad campaign to prove a point: we desperately need more transparency in online political advertisement, starting with our bipartisan Honest Ads Act.
NA
#GetCovered at healthcare.gov, now through December 15th.
Great talking with student newspapers from across the Commonwealth about my bills dealing with college affordability and our nation's student debt crisis.

Doubling the fee for visiting Shenandoah and other national parks is the wrong move. Making park visitors foot the bill for the federal government’s failure to fully maintain our national parks is not the answer.
Today is Election Day here in Virginia. If you haven’t cast your ballot yet, find your polling place here: https://vote.elections.virginia.gov/VoterInformation/PollingPlaceLookup
Virginia voters sent a clear message last night: if you abandon the middle class, the middle class will abandon you. This is not going to end well.
Secretary Gates is right. Ending DACA is bad for our military. We must pass the DREAM Act Now.
The House GOP tax bill is anti-growth and anti-middle class. I’d tell you what I think about the Senate bill, but it’s still being written behind closed doors.
Happy birthday to the U.S. Marine Corps! #SemperFi
Today and every day, I’m grateful to our fellow Americans who answered the call to serve. Thank you for your sacrifice and service to our country, and happy Veterans Day!
Introduced bipartisan legislation this week to help college students and their families make smart financial decisions through enhanced student loan counseling. Learn more:
We need to get serious about the maintenance backlog at our federal parks, but hiking prices at parks like Shenandoah is not the answer.
Just one of the many ways the GOP tax plan hurts Virginia. This is the last thing cities and towns like Staunton who are revitalizing their downtowns need.

Today is National Caregiver Appreciation Day. Unfortunately, the GOP’s partisan tax plan eliminates the exact deduction used to cover in-home care for seniors and people with chronic illnesses. How would eliminating this deduction impact your family?
Don’t wait. Get covered at HEALTHCARE.GOV by December 15th.

Tax Reform should grow the economy, not the national debt. This partisan tax bill might be great for shareholders, but the benefits aren’t going to trickle down to workers, and our grandkids are going to get stuck with the bill.
The House GOP tax bill would eliminate the student loan interest deduction that thousands of student borrowers rely on.   Do you have student loans? Comment with how this will impact you.

Good morning. Overnight, Senate GOP leadership rewrote its tax bill to sabotage the healthcare market and raise premiums by ~10% per year. Big tax cuts for businesses and the wealthy are still in there.
It’s bad enough teachers have to pay out of pocket for the supplies their students need. This adds insult to injury. To the teachers out there, how will this affect you and your students?
NA
When I met Gloria a couple weeks ago, she was excited to graduate law school & serve her fellow Virginians. We can’t waste that kind of potential. We must pass the DREAM Act now.

‪The House just passed its partisan, anti-middle class tax bill. It’s bad for Virginia. It’s bad for America. And the Senate version is even worse. I’m going to fight with everything I’ve got to stop it. ‬

Shameful. Jamming through major legislation with late-night, party-line votes isn't how Congress is supposed to work. Cutting taxes for corporations and the wealthy on the backs of the middle class (and sabotaging the healthcare market) is wrong on every level.

Yesterday’s vote on the House Tax Bill was a direct hit to investment in Virginia’s infrastructure.  This is going to make infrastructure costs skyrocket in Northern Virginia and across the Commonwealth.
This means fewer scientists, fewer engineers, and more student debt.
I'm thankful for my family, friends, and the daily privilege of serving my fellow Virginians in the Senate. From my family to yours, happy Thanksgiving!
November is National Aircraft Carrier Month. Thank you to our U.S. Navy sailors serving around the world and to the hardworking shipbuilders in Hampton Roads.
People are only beginning to realize just how bad the GOP tax bill is going to be for America's seniors.
There is no defense for raising taxes on people making under $30,000 per year. None.
Since Day 1, the main criticism of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) is that it’s *too effective* at standing up for consumers. That speaks volumes.

Today I stood with 16 fellow moderate Democrats who have a proven track record of bipartisan work. Our message is simple: it’s not too late for real, bipartisan tax reform. Not only is there still time, but I honestly believe it will be easier to cut a bipartisan deal with 60 or 70 votes than a partisan deal that only gets 50 Republican votes.  There’s a good reason Senate Republicans are having a tough time getting the votes for their current bill: it raises taxes on the middle class, relies on irresponsible budget gimmicks, and adds $2.2 trillion to the national debt. There’s a path forward here on middle-class tax cuts, a lower corporate tax rate, and a simpler tax code that doesn’t explode the deficit. It’s not too late to start over and get this right. I’m here to be a part of the solution, and so are enough of my Democratic colleagues to pass a bipartisan deal. I hope we can find willing partners on the other side of the aisle.
This is what’s so disappointing about the one-party approach Senate Republicans have chosen on taxes. Bipartisan ideas to help places like Appalachia never made it past the closed doors.
Fortune 500 CEOs say they’ll pass the gains from corporate tax cuts on to investors — not workers.   We should believe them.

We owe it to the American people to do tax reform the right way. A partisan bill that raises taxes on the middle-class, ships jobs overseas, and grows the debt by $2.2 trillion is a missed opportunity.

The Special Counsel’s probe has found illegal behavior stretching into the senior-most levels of the White House. Mike Flynn has pled guilty to criminal conduct, while he was serving as National Security Adviser to the President of the United States, involving his contact with Russian officials. This follows the guilty plea of a Trump campaign aide; charges against a Trump campaign manager; and charges against a key aide to the Trump campaign and transition.   This guilty plea also comes on the heels of a new report about the President’s efforts to silence the independent, bipartisan Senate investigation into ties between Trump associates and Russia. It is part of an alarming pattern in which the President has already fired the FBI Director; pressured the Attorney General and top U.S. intelligence officials to interfere with an ongoing investigation; and contemplated issuing pardons for his associates or firing the special counsel, according to numerous press reports. Members of Congress from both parties must make clear that those actions would be fundamentally unacceptable and incompatible with the rule of law.   The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence takes seriously our responsibility to continue a thorough, bipartisan probe that follows the facts wherever they may lead.

We just now received the text of the 429-page tax bill that we're voting on in a couple hours - complete with illegible, handwritten notes in the margins and entire sections crossed out. Let's be honest: no one knows exactly what's in this bill. But if it were actually a good deal for taxpayers, we wouldn't need to do it this way.

This was a wasted opportunity to do once-in-a-generation, bipartisan tax reform. Instead, Senate Republicans passed a partisan bill tonight that cuts taxes for wealthy on the backs of the middle class and leaves our children with $2.2 trillion in debt.   Even if Senate Republicans had written this bill through regular order — which they didn’t — it wouldn’t have mattered. Leadership rewrote the bill this afternoon and dumped the crumpled, handwritten bill text hours before the vote.  What happened tonight is a disgrace.
There is more to come.
Tim Kaine and I welcomed veterans from across Virginia to the Captiol for our annual Veterans Commonwealth Coffee. It’s always an honor to meet Virginians who’ve answered the call to serve.
Chairman Pai should investigate reports of bots posting fake public comments before any vote on Net Neutrality.
A tax bill that hits places like Roanoke just to pay for tax cuts benefiting the rich and corporate shareholders is a bad bill.

Tim and I have been fighting for months to get Congress to renew the Children's Health Insurance Program — on the floor of the Senate, in committee, in the press, on social media. The leadership in Congress and in the White House need to step up and work with us to extend CHIP for thousands of kids here in Virginia.

Olintequitl is a Virginia DREAMer I met last month. This is his story. This is why I’m fighting to pass the DREAM Act:   “My name is Olintequitl Andres Aguila Soler, I am 21 years old. I was born in small city in Mexico and at the age of six my mom brought me to the US. I was raised by my mother and have lived in Newport News, VA since I was 8 years old. I graduated in 2014 as the Valedictorian of my high school. Though my mother passed away before I could graduate she instilled in me a strong set of moral values and a desire to obtain a college education. Since receiving DACA I have been able to get a decent job, drive, live without a constant fear of deportation, and most importantly work towards my dream of becoming and engineer. I am currently a senior at Virginia Tech studying Mechanical Engineering and hope to graduate in 2018.”
Taxpayers deserve better than this.
December 7, 1941—a date which will live in infamy. Remembering the bravery and sacrifice of those who served at Pearl Harbor.
The FCC should not hold a vote on Net Neutrality until these disturbing reports of fake comments by bots are fully investigated.
AMEN! These four Governors, Republicans and Democrats, are calling on Congress to renew the Children's Health Insurance Program for nine million kids.
There’s no reason to put these young entrepreneurs out of business. We must pass the bipartisan DREAM Act now.
This year’s Warner office Christmas tree is a Virginia Fraser Fir. The front office is looking festive!

Thousands of Virginia families are being notified that their kids who are covered by the Children's Health Insurance Program could lose their insurance if Congress fails to act by January 31st. GOP leadership needs to make this a priority. We shouldn’t go home for Christmas until we renew CHIP.

The Children’s Health Insurance Program provides health insurance for over 66,000 kids and 1,100 pregnant moms in Virginia. Today, their healthcare hangs in the balance because of Congress’ failure to act. We need to put partisan politics aside and fund CHIP now.
Written in secret, passed in the middle of the night, finalized behind closed doors, and now being rushed to a final vote: this bill is Swamp 101.

Republican leaders are using CHIP as, for lack of better term, a bargaining chip. It’s time to stop playing politics with our kids’ healthcare. It’s time to renew funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program.

Today marks five years since the tragedy at Sandy Hook, and unfortunately, five years of Congressional inaction on the issue of gun violence. Congress must come together on common-sense gun safety measures like universal background checks, which the vast majority of Americans support. It’s time for this to end.
TOMORROW is the last day to get covered during Open Enrollment 2017. Visit HEALTHCARE.GOV today.

I stood on the Senate floor in solidarity with the 12,000+ Virginia DREAMers I represent. With each day that passes, more and more of these young Virginians face deportation. They can’t wait any longer. We must pass the DREAM Act Now.
The GOP tax bill actually encourages companies to ship American jobs overseas. It’s anti-worker. It’s anti-middle class.
Senate Republicans released the final version of their 500-page tax bill at 5:30 on a Friday. It’s almost like they don’t want you to know what’s in the bill.
Virginia's DREAMers aren’t asking for special privileges. They’re asking for a shot at the American dream. Congress must pass the DREAM Act now.
NEW: Committee For a Responsible Federal Budget projects that the updated Republican tax bill and its budget gimmicks will add over $2 trillion to the national debt.
Taxpayers deserve better.

The House of Representatives just passed a partisan tax cut for big business and the wealthiest Americans. Taxpayers were promised a “middle-class miracle,” not trillion-dollar deficits and a tax increase for millions of middle-class Americans.
My statement on the Republican tax bill that passed early this morning:
I'm speaking on the Senate floor right now about the future of Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation. WATCH:
FACT: The party that controls both houses of Congress and the White House has failed to renew funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program for 82 days. No more excuses. Fund CHIP now.
NA
From my family to yours, Merry Christmas!
